__section_05_responsibility: à¹€à¸à¹‡à¸š template à¸‚à¸­à¸‡ error messages à¸à¸£à¹‰à¸­à¸¡ placeholders ({digit}, {position}) à¸ªà¸³à¸«à¸£à¸±à¸š dynamic error reporting

templates.CONFIG_LOAD_FAILED: CRITICAL: Failed to load tokenizer configuration from {path}: {error}
templates.INVALID_BINARY_DIGIT: Invalid digit '{digit}' in binary literal at position {position}. Binary literals can only contain 0 and 1.
templates.INVALID_OCTAL_DIGIT: Invalid digit '{digit}' in octal literal at position {position}. Octal literals can only contain 0-7.
templates.INVALID_HEX_DIGIT: Invalid character '{char}' in hexadecimal literal at position {position}. Hexadecimal literals can only contain 0-9, A-F, a-f.
templates.LEADING_UNDERSCORE: Numeric separator '_' cannot appear at the beginning of a number at position {position}
templates.TRAILING_UNDERSCORE: Numeric separator '_' cannot appear at the end of a number at position {position}
templates.CONSECUTIVE_UNDERSCORES: Consecutive numeric separators '__' are not allowed at position {position}
templates.UNDERSCORE_AFTER_PREFIX: Numeric separator '_' cannot appear immediately after number prefix at position {position}
templates.MULTIPLE_DOTS: Multiple decimal points in number literal at position {position}
templates.INVALID_EXPONENT: Invalid exponent format in scientific notation at position {position}
templates.EMPTY_EXPONENT: Exponent in scientific notation cannot be empty at position {position}
templates.NUMBER_TOO_LONG: Number literal exceeds maximum length ({maxLength}) at position {position}
templates.LEGACY_OCTAL_STRICT: Legacy octal literals (leading zero without 'o') are not allowed in strict mode at position {position}
templates.BINARY_OVERFLOW: Binary literal at position {position} exceeds safe integer range
templates.HEX_OVERFLOW: Hexadecimal literal at position {position} exceeds safe integer range

metadata.philosophy: Tokenizer is a 'BLANK PAPER' - knows nothing about grammar, only mathematical character classification
metadata.principle: All grammar decisions must be asked from Brain (GrammarIndex)
metadata.compliance: NO_HARDCODE - All constants loaded from external configuration

__section_philosophy_description: Pure Binary Tokenizer Architecture - Design Principles and Why This Works
__section_philosophy_purpose: à¸­à¸˜à¸´à¸šà¸²à¸¢ philosophy à¹à¸¥à¸°à¸«à¸¥à¸±à¸à¸à¸²à¸£à¸­à¸­à¸à¹à¸šà¸šà¸‚à¸­à¸‡ Pure Binary Tokenizer à¸§à¹ˆà¸²à¸—à¸³à¹„à¸¡à¸–à¸¶à¸‡à¹ƒà¸Šà¹‰ mathematical approach à¹à¸—à¸™ regex
__section_philosophy_responsibility: à¹ƒà¸«à¹‰à¸„à¸§à¸²à¸¡à¸£à¸¹à¹‰à¹à¸à¹ˆ developers à¹€à¸à¸µà¹ˆà¸¢à¸§à¸à¸±à¸š architecture, layered abstraction, à¹à¸¥à¸° comparison à¸à¸±à¸š traditional tokenizers

architecturePhilosophy.title: Pure Binary Tokenizer Architecture - Why This Approach Works
architecturePhilosophy.description: Understanding how this tokenizer reads code through binary mathematics

layeredAbstraction.description: Three distinct layers of binary processing - never confuse them!

LAYER_1_MACHINE_CODE.name: Machine Code (CPU Instructions)
LAYER_1_MACHINE_CODE.description: Raw CPU instructions (opcodes + operands) that control transistors
LAYER_1_MACHINE_CODE.note: WE DO NOT WORK AT THIS LEVEL - Too low, too platform-specific

LAYER_2_CHARACTER_ENCODING.name: Character Encoding (ASCII/UTF-8)
LAYER_2_CHARACTER_ENCODING.note: THIS IS WHERE WE START - UniversalCharacterClassifier reads these values

LAYER_3_SEMANTIC_BINARY.name: Semantic Binary Flags (Our Layer)
LAYER_3_SEMANTIC_BINARY.description: Mathematical classification of characters into meaning
LAYER_3_SEMANTIC_BINARY.note: THIS IS OUR INNOVATION - Pure mathematical token classification

processingFlow.description: How source code flows through the tokenizer

steps.name: File System Storage
steps.description: Source code file stored as binary (0s and 1s) by operating system
steps.example: const x = 5; â†’ stored as sequence of ASCII/UTF-8 bytes

steps.name: Character Code Reading
steps.example: 'c' â†’ charCode 99 (0x63) â†’ mathematical comparison begins

steps.name: Binary Flag Computation
steps.description: Character properties encoded as bit flags (from config)

steps.name: Token Assembly
steps.description: Characters grouped into tokens by asking Brain (GrammarIndex)
steps.example: 'c','o','n','s','t' â†’ Brain says 'KEYWORD' â†’ assign binary 0b00100000

steps.name: Semantic Stream Output
steps.description: Stream of tokens with semantic binary flags

whyThisWorks.description: Advantages of Pure Binary Mathematical Tokenization

LANGUAGE_AGNOSTIC.title: Works with ANY programming language
LANGUAGE_AGNOSTIC.explanation: Only need to teach Brain (GrammarIndex) new grammar rules
LANGUAGE_AGNOSTIC.example: Same tokenizer reads JavaScript, Python, Rust, Go - just swap Brain

PLATFORM_INDEPENDENT.title: Runs on ANY hardware architecture
PLATFORM_INDEPENDENT.explanation: Works at character encoding level, not CPU instruction level
PLATFORM_INDEPENDENT.example: Intel x86, ARM, RISC-V - all use same ASCII/UTF-8 standards

PRESERVES_SEMANTICS.title: Maintains programmer intent
PRESERVES_SEMANTICS.explanation: Source code analysis keeps meaning, Machine code loses it
PRESERVES_SEMANTICS.example: Variable name 'userAge' meaningful in source, meaningless in machine code

MATHEMATICALLY_PURE.title: Zero ambiguity through mathematics
MATHEMATICALLY_PURE.explanation: No string matching, no regex, pure integer comparisons
MATHEMATICALLY_PURE.example: charCode >= 65 && charCode <= 90 is absolute truth, never fails

INFINITELY_EXTENSIBLE.title: Add new languages without rewriting tokenizer
INFINITELY_EXTENSIBLE.explanation: Tokenizer is dumb paper, Brain (config) provides intelligence
INFINITELY_EXTENSIBLE.example: Want Kotlin support? Create kotlin-grammar.json, done

SECURITY_BY_DESIGN.title: All limits configurable externally
SECURITY_BY_DESIGN.explanation: No hardcoded buffer sizes, stack depths, or magic numbers
SECURITY_BY_DESIGN.example: DevOps can set MAX_TOKEN_LENGTH=1000 in config without code change

comparisonWithTraditionalApproach.description: Why traditional tokenizers are fundamentally limited

traditional.approach: Hardcoded regex patterns and string matching
problems: Regex patterns hardcoded in source code
Different tokenizer per language (JSTokenizer, PythonTokenizer, etc.)
Token types as string literals ('COMMENT', 'STRING', etc.)
No mathematical foundation, just pattern matching
Impossible to extend without modifying source code

ourApproach.approach: Pure mathematical character classification + external Brain
ourApproach.example: brain.identifyTokenType(char, input, position) â†’ ask, don't assume
advantages: All decisions delegated to external GrammarIndex (Brain)
Single tokenizer for all languages, just swap Brain
Token types as binary flags from config (0b00100000 = KEYWORD)
Extend by editing config.json, never touch source code

keyInsight.title: The Fundamental Insight
keyInsight.statement: We are NOT reading Machine Code. We are reading Character Codes and converting them to Semantic Binary Flags through pure mathematics.
keyInsight.analogy: Think of it like a prism splitting white light into spectrum. Source code (white light) â†’ Character codes (photons) â†’ Binary flags (colors). The prism (tokenizer) is dumb - it just bends light mathematically. The Brain (GrammarIndex) interprets what those colors mean.
keyInsight.prohibition: NEVER try to understand CPU opcodes. That's the compiler's job downstream. Our job ends at semantic token stream.
keyInsight.boundary: Our domain: Source Code â†’ Binary Token Stream. Compiler's domain: Binary Token Stream â†’ Machine Code.

noHardcodeProof.title: Proving ZERO HARDCODE Compliance
noHardcodeProof.statement: Every single value used by tokenizer comes from this config file
noHardcodeProof.verification: If DevOps changes unicodeRanges.ranges.UPPERCASE_LETTER.start from 65 to 66, 'A' stops being recognized as letter - proving config controls everything
noHardcodeProof.goldenRule: If you can't change tokenizer behavior by editing ONLY this JSON file, you found a hardcode violation

__section_examples_description: Mathematical Approach to Binary/Octal/Hex/Decimal Recognition with Examples
__section_examples_purpose: à¹ƒà¸«à¹‰à¸•à¸±à¸§à¸­à¸¢à¹ˆà¸²à¸‡à¸à¸²à¸£à¸—à¸³à¸‡à¸²à¸™à¸‚à¸­à¸‡ number literal recognition à¹à¸šà¸š step-by-step à¸à¸£à¹‰à¸­à¸¡ character codes à¹à¸¥à¸° error cases

numberLiteralRecognition.title: How Tokenizer Recognizes Number Literals
numberLiteralRecognition.description: Mathematical approach to identifying binary, octal, hex, and decimal numbers

step2.name: Identify Number Base
step2.description: Look at second character to determine base

patterns.binary: Next char is 'b' (98) or 'B' (66) â†’ Binary (base 2)
patterns.octal: Next char is 'o' (111) or 'O' (79) â†’ Octal (base 8)
patterns.hex: Next char is 'x' (120) or 'X' (88) â†’ Hexadecimal (base 16)
patterns.legacyOctal: Next char is digit 0-7 â†’ Legacy octal (deprecated in strict mode)

step3.name: Validate Digits
step3.description: Ensure all following characters are valid for the detected base

validation.decimal: 0-9 (48-57) allowed, plus dot (46) and E/e (69/101) for float/scientific

step4.name: Handle Numeric Separators
step4.description: Allow underscore (95) between digits for readability

step5.name: Check for Suffix
step5.description: Look for type suffix after number

invalidBinary.error: Invalid digit '2' in binary literal (only 0-1 allowed)

invalidOctal.error: Invalid digit '8' in octal literal (only 0-7 allowed)

invalidHex.error: Invalid character 'G' in hex literal (only 0-9, A-F allowed)
invalidHex.fix: Use only 0-9 and A-F after 0x prefix

leadingSeparator.error: Numeric separator cannot appear at start

trailingSeparator.error: Numeric separator cannot appear at end

legacy.warning: Deprecated and forbidden in JavaScript strict mode
